intro: Homeria salmonea, commonly known as the golden trumpet vine, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is characterized by its striking yellow-orange tubular flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. The plant has heart-shaped, velvety green leaves and produces long, twisting vines that can climb or trail along the ground. It thrives in full sun and well-drained soil, making it a popular choice for gardens and landscapes. The botanical features of Homeria salmonea make it both ornamental and ecologically valuable, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
